content: The Act titled "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" allows state social services officers access to federal databases for specific purposes. The Attorney General can grant State social services officers online access to FBI databases for criminal history checks on individuals who have resided with a minor. The Attorney General can authorize State social services officers to access FBI databases for criminal history checks on individuals who have lived with a minor during incidents of abuse or neglect. State social services officers can access FBI databases for criminal history checks on individuals involved in incidents of abuse or neglect of a minor. The Attorney General ensures that officers have "read only" electronic access to the National Crime Information Center for missing persons checks. The Attorney General ensures that State social services officers have "read only" electronic access to the National Crime Information Center for missing persons checks related to investigations of missing children. The term "control terminal agency" refers to a criminal justice agency with direct access to the National Crime Information Center network managed by the FBI. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories. SEC. 3. Access to III by National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. The Attorney General must ensure that specific divisions of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children have access to the Interstate Identification Index, subject to meeting Federal standards for access. SEC. 4. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Privacy protections are in place for information obtained through checks or access under sections 2 and 3, prohibiting any adjustments unless required by law for national security. Information can only be released to other authorized officers or employees. Under section 2(c) and 3(b), officers can only release information to other authorized officers, employees, or persons authorized by law. Knowingly releasing information in violation of this rule can result in imprisonment or fines under title 18, United States Code.
